sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: Recently, a new semiconductor nanomaterial system, all inorganic halide perovskite nanocrystals (IPNCs, CsPbX3, X = Cl, Br, I), have been reported to possess high stability,[1] ultrahigh photoluminescent quantum yield (PL QY), composition dependent luminescence covering the whole visible region with

sections.heading: Healing All-Inorganic Perovskite Films via Recyclable
Carrier Channels of Optoelectronic Devices with High
Xiaoming Li, Dejian Yu, Fei Cao, Yu Gu, Yi Wei, Ye Wu, Jizhong Song, and Haibo Zeng*
sections.text:
The strong ionic character endows all-inorganic CsPbX3 (X = Cl, Br, I) perovskite nanocrystals (NCs) with different chemical features from classical Cd-based NCs, especially when considering their interaction with polar solvents and surfactants. This has aroused intensive interest, but is still short of comprehensive understanding. More significantly, above characteristic may be used to improve the quality of perovskite thin films, which is crucial for the carrier transport inside optoelectronic devices. Here, an interesting recyclable dissolution–recyrstallization phenomenon of all-inorganic pervoskite, as well as its application on room temperature (RT) self-healing of compact and smooth carrier channels in ambient atmosphere for high-performance PDs with high stability is reported. First, according to solubility equilibrium principle, the size of CsPbBr3 crystals can be reversibly tuned in the range of 10 nm–1 μm through washing with polar solvent or stirring with assistance of surfactants at RT. Second, such phenomenon is applied for significant film quality improvement by forming a liquid circumstance within films, which can transport matter at surface and sharp parts into the gaps, healing themselves at RT. This strategy results in large-area, crack-free, low-roughness perovskite thin films. Obviously, such improvement facilitates transport and extraction of carriers in the channels of devices, which has been evidenced by the improvement of performances of the corresponding PDs at ambient condition.

While surfactants are in favor of solution processed fabrication of devices, they will affect film formation process and block carrier transport between particles. Besides, physical and chemical properties of IPNCs will also be influenced or even determined by them to a certain degree.
Meanwhile, crystal structure will influence the bonding effect of surfactants and then their functionalities. In particular, the IPs belong to ionic crystals, which are different from traditional NCs with stronger covalent properties. For ionic
crystals, there is a problem of solubility equilibrium in any solvent, especially in polar solvents. When these ionic IPNCs are modified with surfactants, some distinct phenomena are observed. For example, IPNCs were reported to possess highly dynamic ligands with the diffusion coefficient of surface species greater than 166 μm2 s−1, which are higher than that of tightly bonded ligands.[14] This means a fast exchange of

In addition to the issue of solubility equilibrium, some other problems have also emerged during the solution-based processing of devices with IPNCs. For example, different from traditional NCs, both polar and nonpolar solvents will damage the IPNC films that the subsequent functional layers can only be deposited with vacuum deposition methods.[15,16] Also, elaborate surface passivation and shelling are difficult since further heating will promote sequential growth and ion-exchange reactions are very easy and fast.[6,17] These phenomena indicate the unique surface and structural properties of IPNCs compared to traditional NCs, which should be studied carefully and systematically. Nevertheless, limited reports about surface properties can be found for this interesting while strange material system.[14]
For all types of optoelectronic devices, compact and smooth carrier channels are required for high device performance. Recently, inorganic halide perovskites’s potential applications in optoelectronic devices have been explored.[15,18] As an active layer, the film quality of perovskite is particularly important. However, evaporation of solvent or residual ligands will lead to pinholes and cracks, which is universal in all kinds of solution processed films. Up until now, no excellent strategies have been developed to overcome this inherent limitation for IPNCs. Though methods such as adding surfactants during washing and depositing with addition of polar solvent during centrifugation were put forward,[14,19] they are still unable to meet the requirement of electron transportation. All the problems mentioned above illustrate an urgent need of a comprehensive understanding of the surface and intrinsic structural properties of IPNCs.
In this work, we report on an interesting and universal surface chemical phenomenon of all-inorganic perovskite, i.e., recyclable dissolution–recrystallization, which occurs when controlling the solubility equilibrium of the solution containing perovskite crystals, polar solvents, and surfactants. This can be applied to build compact and smooth carrier channels for optoelectronic devices via self-healing at room temperature (RT). Photodetectors (PDs) based on the treated perovskite film exhibit improved responsivity (>700%), external quantum efficiency (>700%), response speed (1 and 1.8 ms for rise and decay time), and stability, which are better than most of the planar perovskite PDs. This work would expedite researches related to all kinds of inorganic perovskite devices, especially solution processed flexible devices.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The ionic crystal feature of halide perovskites makes them dissoluble in polar solvent, while the ions can also recrystallize when the concentration exceeds the solubility. This mechanism has been applied for the facile and large scaled fabrication of IPNCs recently.[3] The dissolution and recrystallization will not stop until reaching solubility equilibrium. Small amount of polar solvent only results in the dissolution of surface atoms while excessive amount of them will dissolve the halide
perovskites completely. Besides, density functional theory simulations conducted by Kim et al. confirmed that surface ligands possessed weak binding strength. They will desorb as neutral Cs-oleate or Pb-oleate species, easily[19] creating a halogen rich surface of IPNCs.[3] Therefore, such solubility equilibrium is unusual, i.e., it is not only related to material’s intrinsic crystal feature, but also influenced by surfactants. In other words, we can modulate this solubility equilibrium with polar solvent and surfactants simultaneously.
As shown in Figure 1a, according to solubility equilibrium principle, we propose that large particles can be transformed into NCs while NCs can be transformed into micrometer-sized particles during washing through dissolution and recrystallization. First of all, if we dissolve large particles from surface gradually and control the ratio of dissolved part, we can obtain perovskite NCs. This process as shown in Figure S1 (Supporting Information) is like peeling onions and will not stop until reaching an equilibrium state when there are large amount of dissolved species in dispersion. To confirm this hypothesis, we first stirred micrometer-scale CsPbBr3 (Figure 1c) particles in a mixture of toluene, oleic acid (OA). and oleylamine (OAm). As expected, after stirring for several hours, bright green emission from the mixture was observed under a UV lamp (Figure 1d inset). The gradual decrease of particle size is supported by the gradual blue shift of emission peaks (Figure 1b). Though some intermediate shapes were observed during stirring (Figure S2a, Supporting Information), eventually, only spherical CsPbBr3 nanoparticles were obtained with the assistance of ligands (Figure 1d). These spherical particles exhibit good crystallinity as shown by the high resolution transmission electronic microscope (HRTEM) image in Figure S2b (Supporting Information). Wider diffraction peaks in X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns after stirring indicate the reduction of particle size without any phase transition (Figure S3, Supporting Information).
As no external driving force is introduced, the size decreasing process resulted from the influence of surfactants is very slow. It usually takes several days to reach final states (Figure 1b). To promote the dissolution process, we added trace amount of polar solvent, such as dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). Interestingly, the size decrease process was accelerated significantly and the system achieved final state only after 20 min (Figure S4, Supporting Information). Surprisingly, the addition of DMSO did not influence the final PL peak site, implying that DMSO only promotes the dissolution process. Therefore, the solubility equilibrium is mainly dominated by surfactants in this case. No change was observed when large CsPbBr3 particles were stirred in toluene without surfactants, indicating the important roles of surfactants for the evolution of particle size. In contrary, large amount of polar solvents will control the solubility equilibrium instead and excess solvents will dissolve all the perovskite particles. In fact, other polar solvent can also result in similar phenomenon except for the difference in amount according to polarity and solubility. It is worth noting that large amount of highly luminescent NCs can be obtained (Figure 1d inset). Besides, sharp parts with higher energy are dissolved preferentially and results in uniform spherical particles.
In addition to the size decreasing behavior, when one washes the IPNCs, highly dynamic surface species result in efficient washing away of surface atoms bonded with surfactants,

Therefore, after washing for several times, for example, with toluene and ethanol, obvious redshift of PL peaks and color change of powders were observed for CsPbBr3 as shown in Figure 1e. What is worse, the PL QY decreased from 90% to <1% after washing, indicating a dramatic structural change of CsPbBr3 NCs (Figure 1f). As confirmed by the transmission electron microscope (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) images (Figure 1f,g and Figure S5 (Supporting Information)), the particle size grows rapidly during washing. The schematic diagram of size increase mechanism is shown in Figure S6 (Supporting Information). Decreased full width at half maximum of XRD patterns of these samples also implies an increase of particle size and better crystallinity (Figure S7a, Supporting Information), but no crystal phase transition was observed. After washing, the signal intensity related to oleate chains of OAm and OA in the Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra (Figure S7b, region A (Supporting Information)) decreased significantly, which is consistent with above proposed mechanism and the complete loss of colloidal stability during purification. As a result, this surface dissolution and recrystallization process ensures the retaining of cubic crystal structure for bulk CsPbCl3 and CsPbBr1.5I1.5 after growth even though this is a metastable phase at room temperature for bulk inorganic halide perovskites (Figures S8 and S9 (Supporting Information)).[20]
In spite of the phenomenological similarity of this process to common aggregation and self-assembly, the underlying mechanisms are actually different. On one hand, aggregation and self-assembly of nanoparticles only result in large bricks or large area films consisting of small particles. If no additional stimuli and energy are applied, they will not grow together.[21,22] On the other hand, when external energy was applied, for example, self-assembly taking place during material synthesis with heating, obvious orientation growth will be observed.[23] For CsPbBr3 IPNCs, even though size increases by more than 100- folds, no connected regions can be found from the TEM and SEM images. The augmented particles exhibit single crystallinity with regular shapes (Figure S5b,

Except for the relatively small increase of diffraction intensity of (002) plane at 21.6°, no obvious anisotropic growth was observed (Figure S7a, Supporting Information). These phenomena indicate the important roles of dissolution and recrystallization behaviors.
In fact, to achieve high performance optoelectronic devices with traditional solution processed film formation strategy, such as spin-coating, well purification of NCs is the precondition because large amount of residual chemicals will not only influence the film quality, but also block the transport of carriers between particles. This is one of the most important issues leading to poor device performance. Consequently, due to the fact that large amount of residual chemicals in CsPbX3 NC dispersion cannot be excluded by commonly adopted approaches, we are unable to fabricate compact films using conventional spin-coating methods, leading to poor film morphology and also affecting the subsequent deposition of functional layers with solution procedures.[15,16]
Regarding the surface dissolution and recrystallization behavior, we propose to take advantage of this intrinsic structure property to realize localized micro-self-healing of perovskite NC films. The proposed film modification mechanism is illustrated by Figure 2. Here, we take planar CsPbBr3 film as an example and the NCs investigated here are synthesized with supersaturated recrystallization strategy reported in our previous report.[3] For the as-prepared films, there are large amounts of gaps and holes, exhibiting severe discontinuity and high roughness (Figure 2a). When the washing solvent, such as the mixture of ethanol and toluene, is added, a liquid circumstance in films forms. The surface and sharp parts dissolve as M-oleate SaS and the liquid matters wander around and fill the gaps and holes (Figure 2b). Toluene enhances the diffusion dynamics of SaS while ethanol with a greater polarity promotes the dissolution of surface atoms. After the evaporation of toluene and ethanol, the dissolved species between isolated particles will be attached on particle surfaces and recrystallize, forming compact and uniform films (Figure 2c). These dissolved species are like solders, which connect isolated particles, resulting in the increase of particle size and modification of film density and morphology.
The proposed schematic diagram of the micro-self-healing behavior of CsPbBr3 NC film is shown in Figure S10 (Supporting Information), illustrating the initial (1, isolated small particles), intermediate (2), and final (3, connected large particles) states of particles. Detailed procedures can be found in the Experimental Section, which is also shown in Figure 3a. To rebuild the dispersion state of washing, the same ratio of toluene and ethanol are utilized. This proposed phenomenon is somewhat like connecting scattered building blocks into ordered and compact wall or floor (Figure S10, Supporting Information).
Figure 3 shows the SEM images of film evolution after different treating times. Interestingly, as expected, hole size decreased after only one treating compared to the as prepared film (Figure 3b,c). Particle size increases obviously after another treatment (Figure 3d) and after five circles, the film became very compact, with only small amount of cracks (Figure 3e), and most of the holes resulting from evaporation of solvents disappeared. Particle size increased from tens of nanometers to ≈500 nm, which was also confirmed by the color variation of films (Figure 3d,e insets). Additionally, the film become smooth because the sharp parts with higher energy are dissolved preferentially and these dissolved species fill the spaces between particles and connect them (Figure 3g). The elongated decay time of treated film indicates the increased charge diffusion length of the treated CsPbBr3 thin films. Importantly, such ionization of excitons and enhanced charge separation will contribute to both the photocurrent and external quantum efficiency (EQE) of PDs.
Notably, though several reports about film modification for organometallic hybrid perovskites have been reported,[24–28] for inorganic halide perovskite, this is the first time. More importantly, most of previous treating methods are based on polar solvent vapor (DMSO), which require temperatures above 100 °C.[27] Nonetheless, strategy developed here can be conducted at room temperature under ambient conditions, which is in favor of not only the modification of most of the thin-film devices, but also room temperature, solution processed, and flexible optoelectronic devices.
To demonstrate the advantages of this room temperature film treating strategy, planar PDs are fabricated and the device structure is shown in Figure 5a,b. For untreated PDs, charge transport is difficult due to the discontinuity of films (Figure 5a). While for ordered and compact films after treatment, charge
transport and separation under bias will be more efficient (Figure 5b). Besides, charge diffusion length is also elevated with the increase of particle size. The UV–vis absorption spectrum (Figure S13, Supporting Information) indicates that treated CsPbBr3 films have a favorable absorption capability with a direct band gap of ≈2.33 eV, which is in favor of visible light PD. As a result, a responsivity increase of more than sevenfolds, from 0.024 to 0.176 A W−1 for treated PDs relative to untreated ones under biases of 10 V, was observed, as shown in Figure 5c,d. The responsivity increases upon biases voltage, which is comparable with Si PD (<0.2 A W−1) in the similar wavelength band.[29] A redshift of responsivity maximum from 522 to 531 nm was also observed. Meanwhile, EQE, a factor of merit implying the utilization efficiency of photogenerated carriers, is also measured under different biases, as shown in Figure 5e,f. The maximum EQE values at 531 nm increase with the increase of applied biases, reaching 41% at 10 V. Particularly, this value is much higher than that of untreated device, which is less than 6% (Figure 5e). Such approximately sevenfolds increase is consistent with responsivity results, indicating the reduced loss of photogenerated carriers from scattering and recombination. Remarkably, before treatment, the EQE seems to be independent on light frequencies, which is quite different from absorption spectrum (Figure S13, Supporting Information). However, after treatment, the device exhibits a sign of narrowband PD, which is probably due to surface-charge recombination.[30]
Figure 6 shows the detailed characterization of treated PD under ambient conditions. In dark, the current is lower than 1 nA while under the illumination of 442 nm (1.01 mW cm−2) light, the photocurrent can reach up to 7.5 μA under a bias of 9 V, indicating an on/off ratio of more than 8 × 103. The photo current increases drastically under illumination with the increase of applied bias, demonstrating a nonlinear and asymmetric I–V behavior (Figure 6a). This indicates a Schottky contact between CsPbBr3 and gold electrodes interface, which might result from the energy band feature of CsPbBr3 and high work function of gold.[18] From the logarithmic I–V curves of PD (Figure 6b) one can see that on/off ratio is always larger than 103 when bias is higher than 1.3 V, indicating the high light switching characteristic and low power consumption. Furthermore, performance stability for halide perovskites based devices is an important issue for practical applications. When the treated devices were stored under ambient condition (a humidity of 40%–50%) for more than two months, the microstructure is almost the same (Figure S16, SEM image of the film (Supporting Information)) and no obvious degradation
is observed (Figure 6e), indicating the high stability of our device and potential applications in the future. In addition, photocurrent was measured under continuous illumination of 442 nm light with high light flux for more than 8 h, as shown in Figure 6f. The untreated PD presents a serious degradation that photocurrent decreases quickly to 68% after 3.4 h. While, interestingly, under continuous illumination, the photocurrent of treated PD initially increases and then decreases slowly after reaching a maximum value. It is much higher than the initial current and if the maximum current is used as reference, only a negligible deterioration of 4.3% is observed after more than 8 h.

Benefiting from the compact and ordered perovskite films, the PDs can achieve high photocurrent (>10 μA), which can drive commercial LED efficiently. Here, we propose a light power dependent integrated device for encryption communication and the schematic diagram is shown in Figure S17 (Supporting Information). At low light intensity, only red LED can be driven (Figure S18a, Supporting Information). When the light intensity is increased more than ten times, a green LED group can be driven (Figure S18c, Supporting Information). To turn on the blue lamp bank, higher light intensity is needed (Figure S18e, Supporting Information). The integrated devices present intensity dependent switching behavior with good stability and reproducibility (Figure S18b,d,f, Supporting Information), which is consistent with the linear dynamic behavior of single PD. The PD was used to convert the light signal to electrical signal and this integrated device makes such signal visible. Then, we can transmit information and secret key simultaneously with low and high light intensity, respectively, and put forward a decode method. For example, the red device get information (A) and the green and blue device get secret keys (B and C). The final message can be A + B − C.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text: In conclusion, we report on a room temperature recyclable size evolution and micro-self-healing behaviors of inorganic halide perovskites, which result from the surface dissolution and recrystallization of inorganic perovskites with the effect of surfactants and polar solvents. These phenomena are intrinsic and universal for different perovskites prepared with different methods. A film micro-self-healing strategy by forming a poorlike circumstance with the mixture solution of toluene and ethanol is developed according to this mechanism, which can be conducted at room temperature. Compact and smooth carrier channels for devices can be formed, resulting in efficient transport and extraction of photogenerated carriers under bias. Therefore, PD based on treated perovskite film exhibits improved responsivity, EQE, response speed, and stability, which defeats most of the planar perovskite PDs. More importantly, this work would provide good reference for researchers since the developed film modification strategy is facile and suitable for all kinds of inorganic halide perovskite devices, especially for solution processed flexible devices.

sections.heading: 4. Experimental Section
sections.text:
Preparation and Washing of IPNCs: All the reagents were purchased from Aladdin and were used directly without purification. IPNCs were synthesized with hot injection and supersaturated recrystallization strategies according to our previous reports.[1,3] The washing procedures of IPNCs were as follows: first of all, excess ethanol was added to precipitate NCs and supernatant was poured after centrifugation. Then, the NCs were redispersed in 2 mL of toluene and 5 mL of ethanol was added. The dispersion was centrifuged again and such process was repeated for several times.
Ligand Assisted Stirring Preparation of CsPbBr3 NCs: First, 10 mg of CsPbBr3 micrometer particles were added into a mixture of toluene (5 mL), OAm (0.2 mL), and OA (0.8 mL). Then the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 h after which the mixture emitted strong green light under a UV lamp, indicating the size decrease of initial particles into NCs. The photoluminescence would be further enhanced after storing for several days without any treatment. For comparison, sole toluene and mixture with DMSO (10 μL) was used.
Film Preparation and Microhealing: CsPbBr3 NC films were prepared with a one-step centrifugal casting method in which substrates (SiO2/ Si, glass, polythylene terephth (PET), etc., with or without Au integrated electrodes) were soaked in nanocrystal/toluene dispersion (as described above) and centrifuged for 3 min.[32] Film thickness was controlled by centrifugal speed and solution concentration. After the evaporation of solvent, a filter paper was covered on the film and a mixed solution of toluene (4 μL) and ethanol (10 μL) was dropped on the filter. When toluene and ethanol evaporated, this procedure was repeated several times. Notably, all above processes were carried out at room temperature.
Characterizations: To carry out XRD measurements, particle dispersions were drop dried on quartz glasses. XRD patterns were recorded on Bruker D8 Advance. Absorption properties of solution and films were measured with a Shimadzu 3600 UV–vis spectrophotometer. Photoluminescence spectra were measured using a Varian Cary Eclipse instrument. FTIR spectra of powders were recorded before drying in a vacuum oven with a Tensor-27 spectrometer. TEM and HRTEM measurements were implemented with FEI Tecnai G20 on a Cu grid. SEM images of films and particles were measured with FEI field emission electron microscope, Quanta 250F. Fluorescence lifetimes were measured using a Horiba FM-4P time-corrected single-photoncounting system. The film roughness was detected with AFM system, Bruker Multimode 8.
PD Fabrication and Measurements: Planar PD was prepared by casting the NC films on Au/SiO2/Si substrates. The adjacent interval and length of integrated Au electrodes were 20 μm and 0.4 cm, respectively. The EQE and responsivity of PDs were characterized with a Zolix DSR101-UV system equipped with a Si PD as reference. On/off cycling performances and high resolution response time were measured with a continuous semiconductor laser (442 nm) and a trigger under different pulse width.
